text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service

IRM 4.80.1 was published on October 1, 2018 and applied to the Indian Tribal Governments /Tax Exempt Bonds function. The two functions now operate independently of each other in the Government Entities function of Exempt Organizations and Government Entities.
IRM 4.80.1 has been revised to apply to Tax Exempt Bonds (TEB) examinations only.
This IRM provides guidance and procedures for TEB employees in obtaining technical assistance or technical advice.
MATERIAL CHANGES
) Updated previous IRM to remove references and procedures applicable to (
) Edited IRM to replace Rev. Proc.
with Rev. Proc.
) Updated to include various editorial changes throughout the IRM.

This IRM supersedes IRM 4.80.1 dated October 1, 2018. This IRM incorporates Interim Guidance Memorandum TEGE-04-0819-0015, Consolidation of policy statements and delegation orders into two new IRM sections, dated August 23, 2019.
Assistance and Technical Advice
Table of Contents
Assistance and Technical Advice Requests 4.80.1
If a provision of this IRM is inconsistent with Rev. Proc. 2021-2 (or its successor), follow the provisions of Rev. Proc. 2021-2 (or its
This IRM uses the following acronyms and terms:
Acronyms and Terms Description TAM Technical Advice Memorandum TEB Tax Exempt Bonds TEB Exam TEB Exam Groups TEB Technical Technical Group in TEB TLS Tax Law Specialist

TEB examiners (typically, revenue agents) may request technical and/or technical advice when needed. a. Generally, examiners request technical assistance through the TEB K-Net, Technical or Division Counsel. Before you request technical advice, try to resolve technical questions via research and analysis, including discussion with your group manager and peers. You may also get help from: a. TEB K-Net b. An assigned TLS c. TEGE Division Counsel (Division Counsel) You may also get technical advice on examinations from the Associate Counsel. See IRM
, Technical Advice Procedures, and Rev. Proc.
(updated annually). Request technical advice in cases that have any of the following conditions generally discussed in Chief Counsel Directives Manual (CCDM)

, Standards for Requesting Advice and Legal Effect of Advice): a. The law and regulations are unclear as to how they apply to the issue and there’s no published precedent for determining how to treat the issue. b. There is reason to believe that a lack of uniformity in the treatment of issue exists. c. A doubtful or contentious issue is involved in several cases. d. The issue is very unusual or complex and warrants the Associate Counsel’s consideration. e. You believe that securing technical advice would be in the IRS’s best interest. Discuss requesting formal technical advice with your group manager. a TAM (to the extent possible) at the earliest stage of the audit, as in CCDM

If your group manager agrees that technical advice is warranted, contact Division Counsel to discuss the issue with you and your group manager. You must receive a recommendation from Division Counsel before proceeding with a TAM.
(02-23-2021) Requesting Technical Assistance and Technical Advice

a. The law and regulations are unclear as to how they apply to the issue and there’s no published precedent for determining how to treat the issue. b. There is reason to believe that a lack of uniformity in the treatment of issue exists. c. A doubtful or contentious issue is involved in several cases. d. The issue is very unusual or complex and warrants the Associate Counsel’s consideration. e. You believe that securing technical advice would be in the IRS’s best interest. Discuss requesting formal technical advice with your group manager. a TAM (to the extent possible) at the earliest stage of the audit, as in CCDM

If your group manager agrees that technical advice is warranted, contact Division Counsel to discuss the issue with you and your group manager. You must receive a recommendation from Division before proceeding with a TAM.
Discuss requesting formal technical advice with your group manager. Request a TAM (to the extent possible) at the earliest stage of the audit, as discussed in CCDM

If your group manager agrees that technical advice is warranted, contact Division Counsel to discuss the issue with you and your group manager. You must receive a recommendation from Division Counsel before proceeding with a TAM.
Assistance and Technical Advice Requests 4.80.1

Examiners and their group managers may also request help from the TEB K-Net. The TEB K-Net provides technical assistance on general issues or questions, including issues you’re considering in your exam. However, it’s intended to provide case speciﬁc guidance. You may:
Call a TEB K
Net team member for quick and informal technical input on basic questions that will help you independently resolve an issue. Post questions/comments on a discussion forum to begin a peer
to
peer conversation. TEB K

Net team members participate in discussion forum conversations with other TEB tax law specialists (TLS) and examiners. Use Ask A Question to ask for technical guidance or resources that’ll you independently resolve an issue. The assigned TEB K
Net Team Member contacts you to discuss your question. Attend a TEB K
Net event to hear technical information and ask questions. See the TEB K
Net calendar for the dates and times of events.
Caution: Don’t include any PII when using the TEB K-Net. (
) Examiners get approval to request technical assistance from TEB They do this by ﬁlling out necessary forms and providing information to technical assistance request forward. (
) Examiner: If your manager agrees that you’re likely to close the case or as a claim denial, and determines that technical assistance is warranted (with PM’s approval), prepare and send Form

, TEB Technical Assis- tance Request, to TEB Technical manager requesting a TLS for technical assistance. Your request should: a. Identify the taxpayer and bond issue under examination. b. Include your name and your manager’s name. c. Describe the identiﬁed area of noncompliance. d. Include any taxpayer or issuer correspondence with a position on the matter. (
) PM: Approve the group manager’s request for technical assistance, if warranted. (
) TEB Technical manager: a. Notify the group manager and PM of the assigned TLS. b. Discuss the assignment’s priority with the TLS. (

) TLS: a. Review the draft document(s) and prepare a memorandum to the manager and examiner with comments on any areas requiring further development. b. Coordinate with the examiner if additional information is needed. c. Update the TEB Technical manager on case progress. (
) Examiner: a. Respond to any TLS request for additional information. b. Incorporate all revisions into the necessary documents.
Caution: Don’t include any PII when using the TEB K-Net.
(02-23-2021) Assistance from TEB Technical

) Examiner: If your manager agrees that you’re likely to close the case unagreed or as a claim denial, and determines that technical assistance is warranted (with PM’s approval), prepare and send Form
, TEB Technical Assis- tance Request, to TEB Technical manager requesting a TLS for technical assistance. Your request should:
Notify the group manager and PM of the assigned TLS. Discuss the assignment’s priority with the TLS.
Coordinate with the examiner if additional information is needed. Update the TEB Technical manager on case progress.
Respond to any TLS request for additional information. Incorporate all revisions into the necessary documents.
4.80 Government Entities Examinations
) All: Share and discuss pertinent case-related communication during the technical review process. (
) Make informal, and if needed, written requests for assistance to Division Counsel for: a. Legal interpretations b. Case development for “unagreed” issues (
) Get your group manager’s approval before you contact Division Counsel. (
) You may ask for a TLS to help you prepare a request for Division sistance. (
) Generally, an opinion from Division Counsel is conﬁned to the speciﬁc and circumstances of a case. Do not apply the opinion to other cases contacting Division Counsel. (
) Technical advice is advice from Associate Chief Counsel via a technical memorandum (TAM). Either you or the taxpayer may submit a request Rev. Proc.
for assistance on any technical question that develops during your exam. See IRM
and IRM
, Policy
) TAM procedures: a. Follow Rev. Proc.
guidelines (updated annually). b. Offer examiners guidance when they request a TAM and cover their sponsibilities throughout the TAM process. (

) A TAM is a written advice or guidance memorandum furnished by Chief Counsel for legal interpretations and proper application of tax law, treaties, regulations, revenue rulings, notices or other published a speciﬁc set of facts in the examination of a taxpayer’s return, or ation of a taxpayer’s claim for refund or credit, or any other speciﬁc matter under TEB’s jurisdiction.
(02-23-2021) Technical Advice Procedures

A TAM is a written advice or guidance memorandum furnished by Associate Chief Counsel for legal interpretations and proper application of tax law, tax treaties, regulations, revenue rulings, notices or other published precedents on a speciﬁc set of facts in the examination of a taxpayer’s return, or consider
ation of a taxpayer’s claim for refund or credit, or any other speciﬁc taxpayer’s
) Contact Division Counsel before requesting a TAM. See IRM
, Assis- tance from Division Counsel. Note: You must receive Division Counsel’s support before proceeding with a As discussed below, Division Counsel will help you with the TAM request submission. (
) Prepare technical advice requests on Form
, Request for Technical Memorandum. (
) Submit TAM requests to FIP Office of Associate Chief Counsel. (
) Request a TAM (to the extent possible) at the earliest stage of the examina- tion.
Assistance and Technical Advice Requests 4.80.1
Note: Consider using the TEB K-Net or asking TEB Technical for help to determine if you can resolve the issue without requesting a TAM.
) If you think that a TAM is warranted, discuss the issue with your group manager. (
) If your group manager agrees that a TAM may be warranted, they contact PM to discuss the issue. (

) Group manager: a. After you get the PM’s agreement, contact Division Counsel to discuss the issue. b. After consulting with Division Counsel and getting their agreement to request a TAM, get the Director’s written approval before requesting a TAM. c. If the Director agrees that a TAM should be pursued, request a TLS to assigned and schedule a Pre-Submission Conference with Associate Chief Counsel per IRM
, Pre-submission Conference. (
) Examiner and group manager: If Associate Chief Counsel agrees during the pre-submission conference that you should request a TAM, prepare Form

, Request for Technical Advice, with attachments describing the: a. Facts and the issues for which a TAM is requested. b. Applicable law and arguments in support of the IRS position on the issues. c. Applicable law and arguments in support of the taxpayer or issuer positions on the issues. Note: Generally, you should write the facts, law, government’s position, taxpayer’s position and conclusion separately for each issue. Always work with the taxpayer/representative and try to agree on the wording. Note: The assigned TLS and Division Counsel attorney will help you prepare the TAM. See Rev. Proc.
(or successor), Sections

, Request for Technical Advice or Technical Expedited Advice, to the assigned TLS for review.

to the PM for review. PM: After the examiner and group manager address any comments, send Form
to the Director for signature as the approving official on Form Examiner: Notify the taxpayer of the TAM request in writing (Technical Notiﬁcation), using Letter

-A. The taxpayer doesn’t have authority to bar an internal decision to seek technical advice. However, examiners, group managers and the PM may consider and document any objections they receive from the taxpayer. The taxpayer has
calendar days to respond to the Technical Advice cation. If the taxpayer requests more time:
(7) PM: After the examiner and group manager address any comments, send the Form 4463 to the Director for signature as the approving official on Form
The taxpayer has 10 calendar days to respond to the Technical Advice Notiﬁ- cation. If the taxpayer requests more time:
4.80 Government Entities Examinations
a. The taxpayer must: Request in writing, to extend before the

days expire; include the speciﬁc reasons justifying the extended time requested; include a written signature of a duly authorized individual behalf of the taxpayer. b. Examiner: When you receive the written request to extend the

-day period, immediately review it and send it to your group manager with recommendation. c. Group manager: You may approve the written request to extend the day period. You may direct that the taxpayer must send additional documentation to be considered. (
) If the taxpayer agrees with the issues and facts stated in the Technical Notiﬁcation, they should acknowledge agreement in writing. Note: Include the taxpayer’s letter in the TAM request package. (

) If the taxpayer disagrees with the examiner’s statement of issues and facts the Technical Advice Notiﬁcation, the taxpayer must: • Identify each point of disagreement and state the reasons for ment in writing. • Respond completely to the Technical Advice Notiﬁcation. • Include a written signature of a duly authorized individual on behalf the taxpayer.
a. The taxpayer must: Request in writing, to extend before the

days expire; include the speciﬁc reasons justifying the extended time requested; include a written signature of a duly authorized individual behalf of the taxpayer. b. Examiner: When you receive the written request to extend the

-day period, immediately review it and send it to your group manager with a recommendation. c. Group manager: You may approve the written request to extend the day period. You may direct that the taxpayer must send additional documentation to be considered.
(11) If the taxpayer agrees with the issues and facts stated in the Technical Advice Notiﬁcation, they should acknowledge agreement in writing.
Note: Include the taxpayer’s letter in the TAM request package.
If the taxpayer disagrees with the examiner’s statement of issues and facts in the Technical Advice Notiﬁcation, the taxpayer must:
Identify each point of disagreement and state the reasons for disagree
ment in writing.
Respond completely to the Technical Advice Notiﬁcation.
Include a written signature of a duly authorized individual on behalf of the taxpayer.
Note: You and the taxpayer have 10 calendar days to resolve disagreements. See Rev. Proc. 2021-2 Section 7.06.

Examiner: a. If you don’t receive a taxpayer’s written statement or it’s incomplete, may advise the taxpayer that the formal request for technical advice will go forward with the available information. b. If you disagree with the issues and facts presented in the taxpayer’s written statement, try to resolve any disagreement over the issues and facts with the taxpayer. Note: You may ask the assigned TLS for help to resolve any disagree- ments with the taxpayer. c. If you and the taxpayer disagree on the issues and facts, submit a notice of disagreement to the taxpayer. The taxpayer has
calendar days from the date you mail or fax the written notice of disagreement to respond per Rev. Proc.
, Section
Note: The group manager is authorized to extend the

-day period. The taxpayer’s statement of facts and issues must be accompanied by the following declaration: “Under penalties of perjury, I declare that I have examined this information, including accompanying documents, and, to the best of my knowledge and belief, the information contains all the relevant relating to the request for technical advice, and such facts are true, correct, and complete.” Include all statements and correspondence between the examiner and the taxpayer on disagreement of the issues or facts in the formal TAM request. ) If you receive a taxpayer’s written statement and disagree with their state- ments of issues and facts, send a written notice of disagreement to the taxpayer. You must respond even if you determine that a request for advice isn’t warranted. (

) After you evaluate all documents and determine whether a TAM is prepare a written summary of the issues, speciﬁcally for the group manager and the PM, explaining why the taxpayer’s request for a TAM should be approved or denied. (
) Immediately secure e-mail the summary and a copy of the taxpayer’s statement to your group manager. (
) Exam group manager: Upon receipt, forward the examiner’s summary and copy of the taxpayer’s written statement with your recommendation to the (
) The PM may: a. Direct that the taxpayer must send additional documentation to be sidered. b. Deny a taxpayer initiated request for a TAM based on material ment over issues and/or facts. (
) If the PM approves the taxpayer’s request for a TAM, they ask the Director review and approve. (
) If the PM and Director both approve the TAM request, they send their approval to the Exam group manager. (

) The formal TAM request includes the taxpayer’s written statement and all statements and correspondence between the examiner and the taxpayer in connection with any disagreement over issues and facts. (
) If the PM denies the taxpayer’s request for a TAM, the examiner informs the taxpayer in writing. (
) The taxpayer may appeal IRS’s decision to deny the taxpayer’s TAM by submitting to the examiner, within

calendar days after being notiﬁed of the denied request, a written statement of the reasons why it should be referred to Associate Chief Counsel. The statement should include: • Description of all pertinent facts (including any facts in dispute). • Statement of the issue that the taxpayer would like to have • Discussion of any relevant statutory, regulatory, or administrative sions, tax treaties, case law, or other authority. • Explanation of the taxpayer’s position and the need for technical Note: To request an extension of the
-day period, the taxpayer must do so in writing. The PM decides whether to approve the extension request.

) Exam group manager: Upon receipt of the taxpayer’s written request to IRS’s decision to deny the TAM request, send to the PM the taxpayer’s statement, along with the examiner/group manager’s statement of why the issue should not be referred to Associate Chief Counsel for technical (

, Initiating A Request For Technical Advice. b. determines that a TAM is not warranted, he/she will inform the PM the group manager in writing. Inform the taxpayer in writing that we’re denying their TAM request and explain the reasons for the denied request. Note: The Director has
days to deliver a ﬁnal decision per Rev.

) After you secure TAM approval from Division Counsel, the PM and the Director, schedule a pre-submission conference, which is: a. Required for all TAM requests to encourage agreement on the of the issues. b. Conducted with an Associate Chief Counsel attorney, the Division Counsel attorney, the examiner, the group manager, the TLS and the taxpayer. c. Most likely held by telephone and within
calendar days after the examiner is contacted. (
) Before the scheduled pre-submission conference: a. Prepare your own statement of pertinent facts and issues. b. Solicit the taxpayer’s statement of pertinent facts and issues. c. Secure Form

, Power of Attorney and Declaration of for the representative involved with the TAM and verify it covers all cable periods. Note: The legal analysis you and the taxpayer document in your statements reasonably inform Associate Chief Counsel on the issue. (

) The examiner and the taxpayer must exchange proposed statements of the pertinent facts and issues. The proposed statements should include any in dispute, the issues that the parties intend to discuss, any legal analysis supporting authorities, and any other background information that the believe would help Associate Chief Counsel understand the issues that’ll be discussed during the conference. Note: If the taxpayer doesn’t provide a statement of pertinent issues and facts within a reasonable time, don’t delay scheduling the pre-submission ence. Schedule the conference without the statements.

), and send the following information to the Associate Chief Counsel TSS Assignments mail- box, requesting a pre-submission conference. Fax or send the package, by express mail or private delivery service, any part of the information below can’t be e-mailed. • A cover memo, including contact information, requesting a technical vice pre-submission conference. • The name of the office expected to have jurisdiction over the request a TAM. Example: The TEB Exam Group and the Program Manager. • A list of representatives from each IRS function that the examiner ex- pects to attend the pre-submission conference. • A brief explanation of the primary issue. Note: The factual information should cover all collateral issues for which TEB is seeking technical advice from Associate Chief Counsel. Note: The assigned branch of the Associate Chief Counsel office must receive pre-submission materials at least
business days before the conference date. (

) Associate Chief Counsel will contact the taxpayer, the agent, and the Counsel attorney within ﬁve business days of receipt of the request to schedule a pre-submission conference and notify all parties involved of the date, time and conference call number. (

) Examiner: If you, your manager and Associate Chief Counsel decide during pre-submission conference that technical advice: a. Is not warranted, continue processing the case under normal b. Is warranted, continue to prepare and submit the formal technical package. (
) During the pre-submission conference, Associate Chief Counsel may raise issues in addition to those submitted by the ﬁeld office and the taxpayer.

Government Entities (
) Prepare the technical advice package with the assigned TLS’s and the Counsel attorney’s help. The package includes: of the a. Form
, Request for Technical Advice Advice b. Agreed Statement of issue and facts (
copies) c. The Exam group’s statement of law and argument (
copies) d. The taxpayer’s statement of law and argument (
copies) e. Other information for Associate Office consideration, including all ing documents f. Form

, Power of Attorney and Declaration of Representative g. Taxpayer’s Deletion Statement (taxpayer’s request to delete certain taxpayer information) h. Memorandum of Issue(s), Facts, Law and Arguments i. Memorandum-Resolution of Disagreement and taxpayer’s Statement j. IRC

(b) Relief Request k. Documentation supporting Director’s approval of the TAM l. Any other supporting documentation Note: Whenever possible, list the case number and name of the Associate Chief Counsel attorney assigned to the pre-submission conference on all documents. Note: Make sure Form
shows the Director as the approving official and his/ her address. Associate Chief Counsel will mail the TAM to this address. (

) Every request for technical advice must include a description of the facts, issues, applicable law, and arguments supporting the taxpayer’s position on the issues and the IRS’s position on the issues. a. If the taxpayer and the examiner/group manager disagree about ﬁndings of fact or about the relevance of facts, include all of the facts explain the areas of disagreement. b. Include in the memo an explanation of the taxpayer’s position. This ex- planation must discuss any relevant statutory provisions, tax treaties, court decisions, regulations, revenue rulings, revenue procedures, notices, and any other authority supporting the taxpayer’s position. c. Include in the memo a similar explanation of the IRS position. This nation must discuss any relevant statutory provisions, tax treaties, court decisions, regulations, revenue rulings, revenue procedures, notices, any other authority supporting the IRS’ position. d. Both the IRS and the taxpayer should comment on any existing or pending legislation, tax treaties, regulations, revenue rulings, revenue procedures, or court decisions contrary to their respective positions. e. If either party determines that there are no authorities contrary to its position, note this in a statement in the memo. (
) Don’t send the exam case ﬁle with the TAM request unless Associate Chief Counsel speciﬁcally requests it. (
) Keep original documents in the exam case ﬁle. Use copies of these for the technical advice package. (

Every request for technical advice must include a description of the facts, issues, applicable law, and arguments supporting the taxpayer’s position on the issues and the IRS’s position on the issues.

issues, applicable law, and arguments supporting the taxpayer’s position on the issues and the IRS’s position on the issues. a. If the taxpayer and the examiner/group manager disagree about ﬁndings of fact or about the relevance of facts, include all of the facts explain the areas of disagreement. b. Include in the memo an explanation of the taxpayer’s position. This ex

planation must discuss any relevant statutory provisions, tax treaties, court decisions, regulations, revenue rulings, revenue procedures, notices, and any other authority supporting the taxpayer’s position. c. Include in the memo a similar explanation of the IRS position. This nation must discuss any relevant statutory provisions, tax treaties, court decisions, regulations, revenue rulings, revenue procedures, notices, any other authority supporting the IRS’ position. d. Both the IRS and the taxpayer should comment on any existing or pending legislation, tax treaties, regulations, revenue rulings, revenue procedures, or court decisions contrary to their respective positions. e. If either party determines that there are no authorities contrary to its position, note this in a statement in the memo. ) If the taxpayer submits additional information after the conference, the examiner must either provide comments on the additional information to Associate Chief Counsel or notify them that they have no comments. ) Examiner: a. Share the preliminary TAM with your group manager and the assigned TLS and consult with them in identifying any disagreement. b. Don’t discuss the TAM issues with the taxpayer while Associate Chief Counsel processes the TAM request and issues the ﬁnal TAM. (
) When the TAM is complete, Associate Chief Counsel will mail or e-mail the TAM to the Director and a copy to the examiner and the Division Counsel attorney. (
) Examiner: send a copy to your group manager, the PM, and the assigned TLS. (
) Associate Chief Counsel’s reply to a TAM request is in two parts. Each part identiﬁes the taxpayer by name, address, identiﬁcation number and years involved. (

) The ﬁrst part of the reply is a transmittal memorandum. a. Don’t release the transmittal memorandum to the taxpayer. b. Coordinate any request, by any party, for a copy of the transmittal randum with the examiner’s Disclosure Officer. c. In unusual cases, the transmittal memorandum gives TEB other tion that under the nondisclosure statutes or for other reasons may not be discussed with the taxpayer. (

) The second part is the TAM, which contains: a. A statement of the issues. b. A statement of the facts pertinent to the issues. c. A statement of the pertinent law, tax treaties, regulations, revenue other precedents published in the Internal Revenue Bulletin and court decisions. d. A discussion of the rationale underlying conclusions reached by Associate Chief Counsel. e. The conclusions of Associate Chief Counsel. (
